results.headline: Lingering on the Express Line: Bagging Some Humanity Amid Bar-Code Scanners
results.summary_short: Brad Silberling’s new movie has nothing to prove, and not all that much to say, but its modesty and good humor make it hard to resist.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 10 Items Or Less

results.headline: Struggling With Life on a Road to Nowhere
results.summary_short: Nine years in the making and timeless in its observations, “Highway Courtesans” is an intimate look at some of the youngest practitioners of the world’s oldest profession.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Highway Courtesans

results.headline: Ugly Americans, Young, Attractive and Tormented
results.summary_short: If stupidity were a crime, the nitwits in the cheap horror flick “Turistas” would be doing time in Attica.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Turistas

results.headline: The Long and Fatal Reach of an Unyielding Epidemic
results.summary_short: Had it taken a more hard-headed approach, “3 Needles” might have been to the AIDS epidemic what “Traffic” was to the drug trade.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 3 Needles

results.headline: The Virgin Mary as a Teenager With Worries
results.summary_short: Directed by Catherine Hardwicke from a script by Mike Rich, "The Nativity Story" sticks to the familiar details of the narrative and dramatizes them with sincerity and good taste.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Nativity Story

results.headline: Love in the Modern Age
results.summary_short: This innovative chronicle of a truly modern romance conveys, in a painful, darkly humorous way, a variety of ultra-identifiable truths.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Four Eyed Monsters

results.headline: Malaise in the Projects, and Elsewhere
results.summary_short: “The Architect,” written and directed by Matt Tauber from a play by the Scottish writer David Greig, feels like a creaky, tone-deaf classroom exercise in mechanical contrivance.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Architect

results.headline: First the Bickering, Then the Murky Violence
results.summary_short: A moody thriller about an unhappily married couple, a remote cabin and a pair of homicidal crazies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Invisible

results.headline: A Modern Bollywood Treatment of Mischief
results.summary_short: The pleasure principle is palpable in the giddy, slick “Dhoom 2,” a satisfying example of the new, thoroughly modern Bollywood.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dhoom 2

results.headline: Crude, Yes, but With Exquisite Finesse
results.summary_short: John Waters is darned entertaining as he delivers a monologue that annotates his scandalous movies and encompasses assorted other subjects that interest or annoy him.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of This Filthy World

results.headline: What’s for Dinner? You Don’t Want to Know
results.summary_short: Nikolaus Geyrhalter's superb documentary is an unblinking, often disturbing look at industrial food production from field to factory.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Our Daily Bread

results.headline: How Do You Land a Hunk? Act Straight, or Be Yourself?
results.summary_short: A Rubik’s Cube of shifting sexual orientation and elaborate sex fantasies, “Sloppy Seconds” gathers all the accouterments of soft pornography into a plot of stunning imbecility.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eating Out 2: Sloppy Seconds

results.headline: Big Dreams of a Little Girl, and Her Dad
results.summary_short: Obsession flows downhill in an Australian opal mining community as a father hunts for the perfect stone and his 9-year-old daughter nurtures a pair of invisible friends.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Opal Dreams

results.headline: A Garden Hose Bathes Them With Thrills
results.summary_short: When a movie aspires to be gay pornography but can’t even manage that, well, you know you’ve got a bad movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sun Kissed

results.headline: A Love That Tries to Conquer All, Including Past Lives
results.summary_short: In his third feature, Darren Aronofsky tries to replace the prose of narrative cinema with a poetic language of rhyming images and visual metaphors.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Fountain

results.headline: The Heavy Journey to Becoming a Rock God
results.summary_short: This jolly rock ’n’ roll comedy, sprinkled with amusing one-liners and hilarious sight gags, is a spinoff from the short-lived HBO comedy series starring Jack Black and Kyle Gass.
results.display_title: Tenacious D In: The Pick of Destiny

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tenacious D In: The Pick of Destiny

results.headline: After a Big Bad Boom, Clues Lead Anywhere, Even Back in Time
results.summary_short: An action flick in which the gaudy pyrotechnics are nowhere near as jaw-dropping as the screenplay that name-checks not one, not two, but three national tragedies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Deja Vu

results.headline: A Bright Christmas: The Battle of the Bulbs
results.summary_short: Matthew Broderick and Danny DeVito look tired and out of sorts as feuding neighbors, and you can hardly blame them, given this picture’s inept, curdled mixture of sappiness and crude humor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Deck The Halls

results.headline: Diva Meets Fan From Hell? Better Fasten Your Seatbelt
results.summary_short: A French rock goddess (Emmanuelle Seigner) unwisely allows her biggest fan (Isild Le Besco) into her life in this film by Emmanuelle Bercot.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Backstage

results.headline: From the Stage to the Screen, History Worth Repeating
results.summary_short: The current of intellectual energy snapping through the ferociously engaging screen adaptation of Alan Bennett’s Tony Award-winning play feels like electrical brain stimulation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The History Boys
